description.summary: Three monstrous sisters from Greek mythology with the power to turn viewers to stone with their gaze. The most famous is Medusa, the only mortal gorgon, slain by Perseus.
description.full: The Gorgons are three sisters from Greek mythology—Medusa, Stheno, and Euryale—daughters of the primordial sea deities Phorcys and Ceto. Described as having snake hair, brass hands, golden wings, tusks, and a horrifying appearance, they possessed the terrifying power to turn anyone who gazed upon them to stone. While Stheno and Euryale were immortal, Medusa was mortal and was ultimately killed by the hero Perseus. The Gorgons lived at the edge of the world, beyond the Ocean, in a realm associated with Night. In ancient Greek culture, the gorgoneion (a protective image of a Gorgon's head) was widely used as an apotropaic symbol to ward off evil.

etymology.origin: From Ancient Greek Γοργώ (Gorgṓ), possibly from γοργός (gorgós) meaning 'dreadful, terrible, fierce'

related_phenomena.name: Medusa
related_phenomena.description: The mortal Gorgon sister, most famous of the three

appearance.description: Monstrous female beings with horrifying features

features.description: Living venomous snakes instead of hair
Hands made of bronze or brass
Often depicted with tongue lolling out

physical.morphology: Humanoid female form with monstrous features. Depictions vary from beautiful (early Medusa) to terrifying (later traditions).

abilities.description: Anyone who looks directly at a Gorgon turns to stone instantly
Golden wings enable flight (particularly Stheno and Euryale)
Stheno and Euryale are immortal; only Medusa was mortal

patterns: Dwell at edge of the world
Stheno and Euryale pursued Perseus after Medusa's death

medusa.name: Medusa
medusa.offspring: Pegasus and Chrysaor (born from her blood)
medusa.notes: Most famous; originally beautiful in some accounts

range.description: The Gorgons dwelt at the edge of the world, in the far west beyond the Ocean, at the boundary of Night. Some accounts place them in Libya.

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Greek mythology, part of primordial creation stories. Daughters of Phorcys and Ceto, ancient sea deities associated with dangers of the ocean.
origins.earliest_accounts: Hesiod's Theogony (8th-7th century BCE), Homer's Iliad
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to apotropaic magic, boundary guardians, and primal female power in Mediterranean cultures.

timeline.significance: First detailed literary account of the three sisters
Protective Gorgon masks used on temples, shields, pottery
Story of Medusa's death becomes central to Greek heroic tradition
Presents Medusa's backstory (raped by Poseidon, cursed by Athena)

history.modern_era: The Gorgon, particularly Medusa, remains one of the most recognizable figures from Greek mythology. Modern interpretations often explore themes of female rage, victimization, and the male gaze. The image appears in art, literature, feminism, and popular culture.

traditions: Boundary markers between civilization and chaos
stories: Perseus slaying Medusa with mirrored shield
Birth of Pegasus from Medusa's blood
Stheno and Euryale's pursuit of Perseus
folklore.beliefs: Gorgoneion masks were believed to have genuine protective power against evil spirits and the evil eye.

ancient_greek.significance: Central to Greek religion and magic. Gorgon heads decorated temples (Temple of Artemis at Corfu), shields, armor, and household items.
ancient_greek.architectural_use: Temple pediments, particularly the Temple of Artemis at Corfu (circa 580 BCE) features prominent Gorgon

literature: Dante's Inferno (Medusa guards City of Dis)
Percy Jackson series by Rick Riordan
art: Luciano Garbati's 'Medusa with the Head of Perseus' (2008)
other: Feminist reinterpretations of Medusa as survivor
